channel.title: Comments on: How To Get Started With Selenium Core And ASP.NET MVC

item.title: By: jspringer
item.dc:creator: jspringer
item.content:encoded:
Awesome example…great idea for using ASP.NET website as well…I took a few minutes to create a repeater and a code behind on a page to see if ASPX pages would work, and of course they do, so you could create some reusability snippets…

Markup..
< %@ Page Language="C#" AutoEventWireup="true" CodeBehind="ASPXTest.aspx.cs" Inherits="Rock.Ihr.BusinessSolutions.Crib.UI.Web.Mvc.Tests.ASPXTest" %>





This Is My First MVC/Selenium Example Test!
< %#Eval("Action") %> < %#Eval("WhatToDo") %> < %#Eval("ThirdColumn") %>


CodeBehind for ASPX page…
public partial class ASPXTest : System.Web.UI.Page
{
protected void Page_Load(object sender, EventArgs e)
{
SetupRepeater();
}
public class DummyClass { public string Action { get; set; } public string WhatToDo { get; set; } public string ThirdColumn { get; set; } }
private void SetupRepeater()
{
var listOfObjects = new DummyClass[] {
new DummyClass {
Action = “open”,
WhatToDo = “http://localhost:55244/crib/admin/”,
ThirdColumn = “”
},
new DummyClass {
Action = “verifyTextPresent”,
WhatToDo = “You are logged into Crib as an Administrator. The \”Admin Only Tools\” in the NavBar are available to you.”,
ThirdColumn = “”
},
new DummyClass {
Action = “verifyElementPresent”,
WhatToDo = “link=Impersonations”,
ThirdColumn = “”
},
new DummyClass {
Action = “clickAndWait”,
WhatToDo = “link=Impersonations”,
ThirdColumn = “”
},
new DummyClass {
Action = “verifyTextPresent”,
WhatToDo = “Change Impersonation”,
ThirdColumn = “”
}
};

rptInstructions.DataSource = listOfObjects;
rptInstructions.DataBind();
}
}

item.title: By: Igor Brejc
item.dc:creator: Igor Brejc
item.description:
I agree with Dhananjay, I think very soon you will find that the HTML test code approach is very problematic - the tests are fragile and difficult to maintain.
I strongly recommend looking at the Google's PageObject pattern: http://code.google.com/p/webdriver/wiki/PageObjects
item.content:encoded:
I agree with Dhananjay, I think very soon you will find that the HTML test code approach is very problematic – the tests are fragile and difficult to maintain.

I strongly recommend looking at the Google’s PageObject pattern: http://code.google.com/p/webdriver/wiki/PageObjects

item.title: By: Dhananjay Goyani
item.dc:creator: Dhananjay Goyani
item.description:
Well, I never used the way you mentioned - writing test actions in HTML file.
Rather I tie Selenium as a library in nUnit test suite. As a developer it is lot more easier to describe tests in C# than managing the HTML file. The great advantage of creating scripts in C# is that you can leverage all your BL and DL while assertion. It's really fun.
item.content:encoded:
Well, I never used the way you mentioned – writing test actions in HTML file.

Rather I tie Selenium as a library in nUnit test suite. As a developer it is lot more easier to describe tests in C# than managing the HTML file. The great advantage of creating scripts in C# is that you can leverage all your BL and DL while assertion. It’s really fun.

item.title: By: Troy Tuttle
item.dc:creator: Troy Tuttle
item.description: Very nice. Thanks for the kick start on UI testing.
item.content:encoded: Very nice. Thanks for the kick start on UI testing.

item.title: By: Dave the Ninja
item.dc:creator: Dave the Ninja
item.description:
I had started working on a library for integrating selenium remote and FluentHTML (MvcContrib) for the use of fluent coded selenium tests for my applications.
I have just moved to Hong Kong and am awaiting my dev boxes arrival so I look to get cracking on the library again.
Have a look here to see what I have done so far (filed under FluentSelenium)
http://code.google.com/p/davetheninja/source/browse/#svn
As I said its still in its basic state, but I believe it will save me a lot of time in the future + its type safe and refactorable.
Let me know what you think
david at davetheninja dot net
Dave the Ninja
item.content:encoded:
I had started working on a library for integrating selenium remote and FluentHTML (MvcContrib) for the use of fluent coded selenium tests for my applications.

I have just moved to Hong Kong and am awaiting my dev boxes arrival so I look to get cracking on the library again.

Have a look here to see what I have done so far (filed under FluentSelenium)

http://code.google.com/p/davetheninja/source/browse/#svn

As I said its still in its basic state, but I believe it will save me a lot of time in the future + its type safe and refactorable.

Let me know what you think

david at davetheninja dot net

Dave the Ninja

item.title: By: Allen P
item.dc:creator: Allen P
item.description:
Derek,
I have some Java tests (jUnit) using Selenium RC that is being run on the Hudson Continious Integration tool. I haven't tried it with .NET technology, but imagine that you could get it set up on Cruise Control.Net.
Here is a brief snippet using c#, http://seleniumhq.org/docs/05_selenium_rc.html#c. You'll want to organize these tests carefully, as it is unlikely that you would want them to run with all of your other unit tests.
I've also used Selenium as a way of scripting repetitive clicking tasks, but that's really not it's intended use.
Thanks for your article, it was a great read. Hope this helps.
Allen
item.content:encoded:
Derek,

I have some Java tests (jUnit) using Selenium RC that is being run on the Hudson Continious Integration tool. I haven’t tried it with .NET technology, but imagine that you could get it set up on Cruise Control.Net.

Here is a brief snippet using c#, http://seleniumhq.org/docs/05_selenium_rc.html#c. You’ll want to organize these tests carefully, as it is unlikely that you would want them to run with all of your other unit tests.

I’ve also used Selenium as a way of scripting repetitive clicking tasks, but that’s really not it’s intended use.

Thanks for your article, it was a great read. Hope this helps.

Allen

item.title: By: Hernan Garcia
item.dc:creator: Hernan Garcia
item.description: To integrate selenium with your CI process (or at least run it via CI server) we write our test in c# (using nunit). Some info here: http://seleniumhq.org/docs/appendix_installing_dotnet_driver_client.html
item.content:encoded:
To integrate selenium with your CI process (or at least run it via CI server) we write our test in c# (using nunit). Some info here:
http://seleniumhq.org/docs/appendix_installing_dotnet_driver_client.html

item.title: By: derick.bailey
item.dc:creator: derick.bailey
item.content:encoded:
@Allen P,

Yeah, I saw the Selenium IDE stuff but haven’t taken the time to play with it, yet.

Are you integrating the IDE version with a CI server to do automated test execution? I’d love to see some info on that.

item.title: By: Allen P
item.dc:creator: Allen P
item.description: I've been using Selenium for a while, and really like testing UI with it. One feature I wanted to point out, is the capability to write the tests in c#. I've found this a lot easier than writing the tests I html format, and it allows you to more easily test intricate details.
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been using Selenium for a while, and really like testing UI with it.
One feature I wanted to point out, is the capability to write the tests in c#. I’ve found this a lot easier than writing the tests I html format, and it allows you to more easily test intricate details.
